His boss is always getting at him for arriving late.
What do you think she's getting at? I've no idea what she wants.
I can't get at him on the telephone.
What I am trying to get at is whether you want to marry the girl for the money or for her love for you.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: be late paying installments for something
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: If you get behind with mortgage payments, you might lose your home.
John doesn't seem to earn much money, but somehow he manages to get by, though I don't know how.
I find it extremely difficult to get down to doing any revision for examinations. / It's time I got down to thinking about my term paper.
I wonder how he get hold of her address.

synonyms_related_words.turkish_meaning: hoş olmayan bir şeyin (konunun/tartışmanın) içine çekilmek
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I didn't want to to take sides because I didn't want to get drawn into their arguments.
We got off the bus and walked to my house.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: enter a bus, train, plane etc.
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: We got on the bus in İzmir and went up to Ankara.
He doesn't get on with his daughter.
The teacher asked the pupils to get on with some work quietly as she has to leave the classroom.
It took me ages to get over the bout of flu.
You seem to have got over your problems.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: (or "get round to") finally do something after a long delay
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I've finally got round to replying my uncle's e-mail.
The doctors got the man round quickly after the accident.
That child can always get round you and get what he wants.
I want to get through this project as soon as possible. / Hurry up! We must get through these papers before 5 o'clock.
Aylin got through her exams without too much trouble.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: be officially accepted, make something accepted
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: They managed to get bill through Congress despite strong opposition.
Thousands of refugees will die if these supplies don't get through to them.
I explained it carefully, but I just couldn't get through to her.
I find it impossible to get through to her.
When I get to my office, I'll look at the matter carefully.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: yield to, surrender, give up, back down
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: If you cannot continue with struggle, you may just as well give in now.
You mustn't give in to blackmail.
The mixture was giving off a strange smell.
You must give out these books as the people arrive.
The bomb fell, giving out a huge flash of fire.
The government's economic policy gave rise to a lot of bankruptcies.
I urged him to give up smoking.
It was a difficult time, but he never gave up hope.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: be replaced by, be superseded by
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Everywhere, small family businesses are giving way to large and impersonal corporations.
How should I go about these things?
He knows how to go about these things.
The construction of the bypass went ahead despite the protest from environmentalists.
If the verdict goes against me, I'll lose my home.
I didn't really agree, but I went along with the decision because I was in the minority.
The government has gone back on their promise not to raise taxes. / No one trusts Akın because he goes back on his words.
Her behavior goes beyond mere enthusiasm; it's obsessive.
As the months went by, we got used to living in this mountain village.
The price of scanners has gone down recently.
The swelling has gone down a lot.
She went down with a virus.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: go to hospital for treatment, surgery etc.
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: He went in for a triple bypass operation two days ago.
The milk went off because I forgot to put it in the fridge.
The gun went off accidentally.
The Second World War went on until 1945.
We need to go over these accounts again. / The auditors went over the accounts with great care.
I went through my notes before the exam.
He went through the details of the plan over and over again to make sure that there was no possibility of failure.
He has gone through a lot of pain and suffering since his son was killed in an accident.
The price of petrol has gone up sharply because of the increase in duty in the Government's budget.
She went up to him and asked him if he wanted a drink.
Does this tie go with my shirt? / The colors in the room go with each.
I had to go without lunch today because I didn't have any time.
He grew out of those shoes in no time at all.
He grew up in İstanbul.
They hammered out their differences and got the contract signed.
A new deal was hammered out between two banks.
Traditional stroytelling skills were handed down through the generations.
He handed in his resignation yesterday.
The teacher handed out the test booklets at the beginning of the class and collected them when the time was up.
She doesn't want to hand over the propery to anyone.
They hang around the station most of the day.
Hang on for a moment, please.
He has a dark suit on.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: travel towards, be on the course for
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The car was heading for Eskişehir.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: be on the course for, go towards
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: She is heading for a nervous breakdown. / The country is heading for a political crisis.
The speaker seemed intent on heading off awkard question.
She heaped food on my plate. / She heaped my plate with food. / Rocks were heaped up on the side of the road.
I believe she will do her best to help us out.

synonyms_related_words.turkish_meaning: depend on, be dependent on, rest on
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Everything hinges on the outcome of the talks between two leaders.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: (or "hit upon") arrive at, find, think of, discover
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I suddenly hit on the solution. / I hit upon the solution to this problem almost by accident.
It was really hard to hold back the tears. / They are used to hold back their emotions.
Lack of funding held the project back.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: not disclose information, withhold, refuse to give, conceal
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The government held back the findings of the report for fear of alienating voters.
We could get a new computer now or hold off until prices are lower. / Could you hold off making your decision for a few days?
Could you hold on for a minute; she'll be free in a moment?
I held on to my luggage while I was waiting for the taxi so that it wouldn't get stolen.
When the enemy attacked, they held out for six weeks.
How long will our food supplies hold out?
She hold out her arms to embrace her friend.
The meeting has been held over till Friday.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: remain in one piece and not break apart, not break, unite
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The society managed to hold together despite the crisis.
I was held up by the terrible traffic and arrived half an hour late for my appointment.
Two armed man held up the bank in High Street this morning and got away with £75000.
The student held up his hand to ask the teacher a question.
I don't hold with their plans.
He was pleased to learn that many of his suggestions had been incorporated into the plan.
I inferred from his answer to my questions that he was trying to conceal something.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: give to, impose on cause (damage, harm or unpleasantness)
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Our soldier have inflicted heavy losses on the enemy. / Before the abolition of capital punishment, the death sentence was inflicted on criminals who committed serious crimes, such as murder in Turkey.
His strict upbringing inhibited him from expressing his thoughts and feelings freely.
The police will inquire into the events leading up to this situation.
You must avoid interfering in matters that do not really concern you.
Nothing should be allowed to interfere with our search for the truth.
The management team ironed out the tax problems before they gave the project the OK.
He joined in the children's game. / I invited her to join in the conversation.
I jotted down her number on a scrap of paper and I can't find it now.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: (or "stay abreast of something") stay up to date with, stay in touch with, be in touch with
synonyms_related_words.turkish_meaning: izlemek, (son gelişmeler hakkında) bilgi sahibi olmak
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: We keep abreast of the developments in our country and in the world through mass media.
I keep a dictionary around when I'm doing my homework.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: continue with something difficult, persist in
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: She found the course hard but she kept at it and completed it successfully. / You will never learn German well unless you keep at it.
Medicines should always be kept away from children.
He keeps away from alcohol and tobacco.
The police accused him of keeping back important information.
Doctors are trying to keep down the epidemic.
I couldn't keep from arguing with her. / You must keep from alcohol.
The teacher kept the student in after school because they had misbehaved.
She kept off the subject of her divorce.
Keep off the grass in the park, please.
Ali kept on trying and succeeded in the end. / He keeps on interrupting me.
The police kept the demonstrators out of the building.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: match, be equal with, be level with
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: In recent years, wage rises have kept pace with the rate of inflation.
Please keep to the path.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: stick to, adhere to, abide by
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Our discussion time is limited, so we must keep to the subject.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: not let someone go to bed
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: My neighbors kept me up till after 4 am with their loud music last night.
Our athlete keeps up his lead in the races.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: move at the same rate, keep pace with, stay even with
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: He walks too fast and it's really hard to keep up with him. / Salaries are increased regularly to keep up with inflation. / The provision of accommodation for students in Turkey has not kept up with the increase in places at the universities and technical colleagues.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: stay in touch with, keep in contact with, keeps abreast of
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I try my best to keep up with the latest developments in my subject. / Ayla is one of those women who always keep up with the latest fashions.
We kicked the idea about the meeting.
I used to kick around with them, but haven't seen them for a while.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: when the drug starts to take effect
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Her hay fever didn't feel half as bad once the antihistamines had kicked in.
The match kicks off at three o'clock. / The Doha development round kicked off in 2001.
He kicked off last month when he had a massive heart attack.
The family kicked the au pair out when they found out that she was planning to move to work for another household.
They are going to knock down all these old buildings and build new apartment blocks in their place.
The girls lagged behind picking flowers.
The rules of the sport were laid down early in the nineteenth century.
The Prime Minister urged the rebels to lay down arms.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: make an employee redundant, cut back on
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The textile factory has laid off half of its workers because of falling sales.
Please leave out the last ten names on the list.
He's grown so much, we'll have to let his trousers down.
We hope that she won't let us down.

synonyms_related_words.turkish_meaning: içeri almak, içeri girmesine izin vermek
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The doorstaff didn't let him in the nightclub because he was wearing jeans.
The judge let him off with a fine rather than a prison sentence since it was his first offence. / The offender was let off with a fine as it was his first offence.
The convict was let out of prison after serving five years of an eight-year sentence.
He let out a huge sigh of relief when he heard the results.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: become level, become stable and unchanging
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The production has levelled off, and we don't expect it to rise in a few months.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: have as a basis, dwell, belong, consist, pertain
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Success in this business lies in advertising. / The strength of his performance lies in his training. / The foundation of personal and professional success lies in understanding yourself.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: be up to, be dependent on, be decided by
synonyms_related_words.turkish_meaning: ...e kalmak, ...e bağlı olmak, ... ile / tarafından belirlenmek
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The choice lies with you. / Your success lies with the actions you take each day. / In the end, the decision lies with the manager.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: stay behind, delay leaving, hang on
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: A large number of people lingered about the concert hall to get a glimpse of their favorite singer.
He lives for football.
Can you manage to live on twenty-five dollars a week?
He's been dead for many years, but his name lives on.
It was hard to live through the recession, but we managed it.
We hope they will live up to our expectations. / We will continue to live up to our promises.
Their auntie looked after them while their mother was an hospital.
Erdal looks back on his failure with regret.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: have a low opinion of someone, disdain, despise, scorn
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: He looks down on his colleagues because he thinks he's better than they are. / Teacher should not look down on their students.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: try to find, search for someone or something
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I've been looking for all their hidden files, but I can't find them anywhere.

synonyms_related_words.turkish_meaning: dört gözle beklemek, iple çekmek, can atmak
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I'm really looking forward to meeting you. / She looks forward to seeing you again.
We'll look into the problem and come back to you when we have the information. / The police are looking into the matter.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: watch something like a crime without helping
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The crowd just looked on as the old lady was mugged.
I look on her as a close friend.
Look out; you're going to drop that! / You should always look out for the traffic.
They came to look the house over with a view to buying it. / The teacher will look over our test tomorrow.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: consult a reference work, try to find a particular piece of information
synonyms_related_words.turkish_meaning: bakmak, belirli bir bilgiyi bulmaya çalışmak
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I didn't know the correct spelling of the word so I had to look it up in the dictionary. / I looked up the address in the phone book.
Young people should look up to their parents and teachers.
I look upon him as a close friend.
The thieves made away with our silver and china.
We made for home and when it started raining.
This incident will not make for the warring factions.
Many churches have been made into flats in recent years.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: try to compensate for doing something wrong
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: He tried to make it up to her, but she wouldn't speak to him.
What do you make of the idea?
The only witness to the accident made off before the police arrived.
Thieves made of with over a million dollars in the robbery.
I couldn't make out the words of the song. / I can't make out what he means.
He could just make out a dark shape moving towards him.
How are your children making out at the new school?
Please make the cheque out to RGM Production Ltd.
He made out that he was ill so that he didn't have to go to school.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: transfer the title or possession of something
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Mr. Smith made over his business to his son.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: stop being angry with someone, become reconciled, become friends again
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The are always arguing, but they make up again very quickly.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: invent, create (an explanation, a story/poet, etc.)
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The made up an excuse for being late.
The fashion model makes up her face before a job.
Eleven players make up one team.
The maid will make up the room.
I sent her a present to try to make up for my appalling behavior.
Make with the money you owe me.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: plan in detail how something will happen
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Her own future had been mapped out for her by her parents.
The climbers mapped out the area throughly.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: consider someone or something to be a certain group, type etc.
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I marked them down as conservatives, but they're very liberal.
I marked off the items on the list as I finished them.
His dedication marked him out for great things.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: stand out because of certain qualities
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Her speed marks her out from the rest of the group.
The instructions weren't clear, so everybody was mixed up .

synonyms_related_words.synonym: put things together without any order
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I sorted all the papers and you've mixed them up again.

synonyms_related_words.turkish_meaning: değiştirmek bir konuyu ya da işi
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: She moved on the another company where the salary was considerably better.
The police moved the crowd on because they were holding up the the traffic.

synonyms_related_words.turkish_meaning: çıkışmak, başının etini yemek, içine dert olmak
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: My boss is always nagging at me about my arriving a few minutes late for work. / The feeling that I shouldn’t have given up nagged at me.
Some people nodded off during the speech.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: write something down so that you will have a record it
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: She noted down my fax number so that she could send me the documents when she got to the office.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: enter one's mind, cross one's mind, dawn on
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Didn't it occur to you to help me when you saw how much trouble I was in?

synonyms_related_words.synonym: start to talk freely about something
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: She hates to open up and discuss her feelings.
I opted for an endowment mortgage and lost a lot of money.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: decide (choose) not to take part in something
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: You made a promise to them, and you can't opt out now.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: be indebted to, be obligated to, be beholden to
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: She owes her success to hard work and determination.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: put things into a bag, suit case, or box so that you can take or send them somewhere
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: He packed up all his belongings in an old suitcase and left the same day.
We had nothing left to do, so we packed up early.
The dancers have been paired off.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: take part in, engage in, join in
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: A large number of teachers participated in the in-service training program.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: give something out to a group of people, distribute
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The teacher passed the handout around.
Although not qualified, he managed to pass as a doctor for years.
Sadly, Georgia's uncle passed away yesterday after a short illness.
I was passing by her house the other day when I heard about it.
I was feeling ill, but the feeling has passed by.
I'll pass the message on when she gets here.
Her husband passed on last year.
Let's pass on to a new subject.
She passed out when the temperature went up to 44 degrees.

I didn't see much as I was only passing through the town.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: give ownership or responsiblity to someone
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The shares passed to his daughter when he died.
He had to sell his land to pay off his son's debts.
This looks like being an occasion when hard work will pay off later than sooner.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: take away, remove slowly(gradually) over a period of time
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: It will take a long time to phase out obsolete laws.
She picked out the ones she wanted to take and left the rest.
The victim couldn't pick out her attacker from the photos the police showed her.
After the interruption we picked up where we had left out.
I am glad to say that he is picking up again. / Sales picked up a bit during the Christmas period.
She has picked up elementary Turkish in a few months. / She picked up Spanish in six months.
We have picked up a lot of information about the area in a short time.
The driver stopped to pick up a hitchhiker.
His debts have been pilling up for months.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: try to make something seem less important
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The Government has tried to play down the importance of the minister's resignation.
I'm playing up to my boss at the moment because I want the promotion.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: connect machines to the electricity supply
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: He plugged the TV in and turned it on full blast.
The teacher pointed out that his student has made considerable progress thanks to his innovative techniques.
I need to polish up my French before I go to Paris.
He popped in for a coffee on his way home.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: separate two people or animals that are fighting
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: A fight broke out in the pub and it was hard to pull the people involved apart.
She pulled the machine apart to see what was wrong with it.
They pulled the old cinema down to build a new shopping mall.
The illness has pulled him down.
The train pulled in and we rushed to meet her as she got off.
Their last hour pulled in millions of fans.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: stop by the side of the road
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The police pulled the car over.
She was badly injured in the accident last week, but she will pull through. / The doctor says the injured passengers will pull through.
The cab pulled up outside my house and I got out.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: (or "place a strain on") place a demand on, put a burden on
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The huge trade deficit put a severe strain on the Turkish economy.
She is quite successful in putting her ideas across.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: ignore, set aside one's own feelings or priorities for the sake of others
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Murat put his grief aside and started work again.
I tried to put some money by every month towards our summer holiday.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: kill an animal because it's old, ill etc.
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: He had put down his dog because it was in a lot of pain from its tumors.
The scientist put forward an interesting theory regarding the expansion of the universe.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: install, make something ready to use
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: They had to put in a whole new central heating system because the house was so cold.
The concert's been put off until next month because the singer's got a throat infection.
I was really put off by the way he eats with his mouth open.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: discourage from, deter from, stop something doing
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: He has been put off by his offensive remarks. / This snowstorm might put them off coming.
He was trying to study his lessons, but the continuous noise outside put him off.
His strange manners put many people off.
He's put on a lot of weight since he gave up smoking.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: dress in, have something on, wear
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: We have to put on our best clothes for the party.
Several charities put out an appeal on TV for money for the victims of the flooding in Mozambique.
Would it be putting you out greatly if I asked to change to another day?
He put out his cigarette before entering the building. / The rain put out the huge forest fire.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: (or "go out of business") cause somebody to lose his job or business
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: If a major manufacturer is in serious difficulties, the suppliers and contractors dependent on him may be put out of business.
Could you put me through to extension 259 please?
She put $250 towards the cost of the repairs and we had to pay the rest.
She put me up for the night because I'd missed the last bus and there were no night buses running.
The government has put tution fees for undergraduate students up again.
He put up a good proposal. / The put up a new candidate for the position.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: make a particular effort to achieve/prevent something
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: They put up strong resistance.
I will not put up with his laxness any longer. / It is difficult to put up with people who are impolite.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: try to persuade someone to do something (to accept something)
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: They tried in vain to reason with the gunmen. / I tried to reason with her but she wouldn't be reasoned with.
He had not reckoned with the severity of the winter weather.
Picasso was a massive overpowering presence to be reckoned with much as Michelangelo had been is his old age.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: (reconcile someone to something) make someone accept a situation
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: She couldn't reconcile herself to the new and reduced circumstances she found herself in.
When she reflected on her marriage, she had to acknowledge to herself that it had been great mistake.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: avoid(hold) oneself back from doing something
synonyms_related_words.turkish_meaning: kaçınmak, bir kişiyi bir şey yapmaktan alıkoymak
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Please refrain from smoking within the hospital buildings.
He is researching into the reading problems of young school children.
Terrorists resort to bombing city centers as a means of achieving their political aims.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: be up to, belong with, reside with
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: It rests with you settle your differences as best you can. / The responsibility for the decision rests with the principal.
The police had difficulty restraining the crowd from attacking the murderers.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: (restrict yourself to something) limit to, confine to
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Camping is restricted to five designated campgrounds.
Much good may result from his intervention in the dispute.
The Interior Minister reverted to point several times in the course of his speech.
I phoned and left a message this morning but she still hasn't rung me back.
Dave rang off guiltily when he saw his boss coming.
He hasn't rung me up yet.
I ripped up all the letters she’d sent me.
The competition rolled on despite the administrative problems.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: appear in large numbers for an event
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Thousands rolled up to see the stars at the film premiere.
The wood rotted away and the window fell out.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: eliminate, exclude, leave out, not consider, dismiss, disregard, prevent
synonyms_related_words.turkish_meaning: dışlamak, olasılık dışı bırakmak, olanaksız görmek(kılmak), engellemek
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The manager ruled out the possibility of a pay rise. / Police have ruled out murder but are still holding several people for questioning. / Police said arson could not be ruled out. / The snowstorm ruled out our weekly rehearsal.
I ran across an old friend in the library.
He ran away from his attackers.
This situation runs counter to ordinary logic.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: campaign for a position, be a candidate for
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: She's thinking about running for the presidency. / He will run for mayor.
I ran into James in a bar in the City on Friday.
Ali lost control of his car and ran into a lamp post.
The project has run into millions of dolars without any prospect of a return on this investment. / Flood damages could run into millions.
Could you run off fifty copies of this report, please?
The van runs on diesel.
Time is running out.
Our food supplies are running out. / The petrol is running out.
We are running out of petrol.
Could you run over that point again; I'm afraid I didn't quite understand it?
The driver couldn't stop in time and ran the fox over when it ran in front of his car. / Two children were run over at that intersection yesterday.
The cast ran through the play the day before it opened to the public.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: go over, go through, explain(read) something
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Let's run through the essay topics suggested by the teacher.
He ran up against trouble in his new job.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: save, accumulate money for future use
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: She has saved up $500 in three months.
There are toys scattered about the room.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: say goodbye to someone (by going to the airport, station, etc.)
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I went to the station to see my friend off.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: continue with something to the end
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: They had a lot of difficulties in implementing the project, but the team saw it through successfully.

synonyms_related_words.turkish_meaning: yalan söylediğini farketmek, ardındaki niyeti sezmak
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The police quickly saw through her disguise and arrested her.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: look after, take care of, deal with
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: He saw to the arrangements and everything ran smoothly and efficiently.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: ask someone to come and help, call for
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I had to send for a plumber because the radiator was leaking. / We sent for a doctor when he fainted.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: order people into a location to handle a problem, deliver, forward
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The police were sent in to quell the riot as the protesters had started burning cars and wrecking shops. / If you want to enter the competition, you have to send in for an entry form.
I must get the parcel sent off tomorrow.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: expel a sports player from a match
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Our team's key striker was sent off for arguing with the referee's decision.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: send something to a lot of people
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: They sent out an e-mail to all their existing customers.
The factory sends out toxic gases into the surrounding countryside.
I don’t feel like cooking – let’s send out for a pizza.
Those convicted of murder are no longer sentenced to death.
Mary's unpunctuality served as an excuse to get rid of her.
We set about the cleaning and got it done before lunchtime.
We mustn't eat all the canned food. We must set some of it aside for a possible emergency.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: get rid of, dispense with, forget
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: In dealing with the man, he set aside the instinctive mistrust of him.

synonyms_related_words.turkish_meaning: iptal etmek, geçersiz saymak, geri çevirmek
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The Appeal Court set aside the guilty verdict because the evidence was unsatisfactory and declared her not guilty.
The Prime Minister set forth the aims of his government in a speech he made at the party congress.
A new vogue in hats seem to have set in.
Terrorists set off a car bomb in the city centre last night. Fortunately, no-one was hurt or killed.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: ring an alarm, make something start working
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The smoke set the alarm off.
We set off for our journey, when the weather clears up.
The company set off its overseas debts against it profits at home.
The explorers set out for the South Pole yesterday morning.
The company set out to create a new product that would revolutionize the industry.
The museum set out a collection of rare artifacts from ancient civilizations.
The team set out to redesign the website to make it more user-friendly.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: install, assemble, prepare equipment/software etc. for use
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The technician set up the computer network perfectly.
The Minister of Commerce set up an emergency committee yesterday to ensure the maintenance of bread supplies.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: stop moving from place to place, live a quieter life
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: After years of partying and drinking, she finally got married and settled down.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: establish oneself in a new home(location)
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: He is a person whose aim is to settle down in a safe job.
We were upset not to win and had to settle for the second prize.
He decided to settle in Antalya after his retirement.
It took him a while to settle in when he moved to Japan.
They couldn't agree at first on a name for their daughter, but finally settled on Alice.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: (or "throw/cast light on something") provide new information that helps you understand something
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The report sheds light on the causes of the escalation of violence.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: stay until the end of something (especially dull)
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I was bored and wanted to leave halfway through, but we sat through the film.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: have a speciality, dedicate oneself to, focus on
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: In the second year of the degree course you can choose one of the four areas to specialize in.
She spends too much money on clothes.
Research suggests that children whose parents split up are more likely to drop out of school.
It is our job to stamp out any abuse of political power.
He said he would stand by his promise.
If they try to make you resign, we will stand by you.
She was asked if she was going to stand down in favor of a younger candidate.
I'm not going to stand for their rudeness any longer.
The letters BBC stand for British Broadcasting Corporation.
She stood out from the crowd in selection and was offered the job.
One single issue stood out as more important than any other.
They are standing out against any change in the law.
The students stood up when the teacher entered the classroom.
Pope John Paul's prayer inspired the Polish people to stand up against Communist rule.
This coat will stand up to the roughest weather conditions.
She stood up to police when they tried to corrupt her.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: leave an official position or job, especially so that someone else can take over, step down
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Everyone thinks that the Prime Minister should step aside so that someone new can lead the party into the election.
The CEO stepped down after the share price dropped.
The police have stepped up the pressure on beggars in the streets. / The factory has stepped up production.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: defend, uphold, side with, stand by
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I am sticking by my principal in this manner.
He stuck his head out of window. / There is a big nail sticking out of the wall.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: abide by, stand by, adhere to
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: It is advisable to stick as close to the truth as possible.
You must stick with our original plan.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: stay close to, remain with, stick close to
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: During the hike, the group was told to stick with their partners and not stray off on their own.
Alpay likes to stir up trouble by causing arguments. / The controversial speech stirred up strong emotions among the audience.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: take legal action against, go to court, take to court
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: If you suffer injuries as a result of the negligence of your employer, you can sue him for damages.
The news that we heard really took us aback. / We were taken aback by his rudeness.
He takes after his father.
The police took the protestors away.
Don't think of the children while you are away. I will take care of them.
I take it for granted that you will support me in my campaign.

synonyms_related_words.turkish_meaning: olağan kabul etmek, nasıl olsa ... olacağını düşünmek
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Ercan is a man who takes nothing whatever for granted.
The lecture was rather boring and I didn't take in much of what the lecturer said.
She took me in with her story until someone told me the truth.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: take into consideration, consider, bear in mind
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The teacher must take into account the needs of their students when preparing a course syllabus.
They've taken ten percent off designer frames for glasses.
Oil prices have taken off in recent years.
He took off his shoes and dried his feet.
The airplane took off for London at 9 o'clock.
The plane stopped at Zurich to take on some passengers.
She took on the task of indexing the book. / He has taken on too many responsibilities.
The council has had to take on twenty extra employees to handle their increased workload.

synonyms_related_words.turkish_meaning: belirli bir anlam veya nitelik kazanmak
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The President's word have taken on a new significance in the light of recent events.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: get something from the place it is in
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Aylin opened her purse and took out a lira coin.
This liquid is good for taking out stains. / If you don't want me to take out the tooth, I can try and save it.
A new leader took over the government. / Jack took over the business from his father last year.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: obtain(assume) control of something, take control
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The bank was taken over by a Belgian bank that needed to buy a bank to get into the Turkish market.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: be involved in, participate in, join in, engage in
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: She takes part in some extracurricular activities in her spare time.
She takes great pride in being selected for the scholarship.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: take a liking to, rejoice, like
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: He's taken to wearing a cap since his hair started thinning more noticeably.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: go outside on the streets, express opposition to something publicly and often violently
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Thousands of people took to the streets to protest against the government's decision.
This work will probably take up most of my time.
You really don't seem able to deal with my problem so I'll have to take up this matter with your head office.
We tried to talk him into becoming a candidate.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: (talk someone out of something) dissuade from
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: It took me hours to talk him out of his decision to resign from his post.
The entire committee will talk over the proposals.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: use(exploit) a plentiful resource for your benefit
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The company is hoping to tap into the Chinese market.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: see a difference between two people or things
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: They're identical twins so I cannot tell them apart.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: imagine, visualize, dream up, conceive of
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I've been thinking of you ever since you left me.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: carefully consider, plan something in detail
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I shall have to think this matter out before making my final decision.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: consider, ponder, weigh up, reflect on
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: You must think over my offer before making my final decision.
They threw away the rags.
The lecturer touched on theoretical physics.
It took me ages to track them down in the crowd at the football game.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: give something old as part of the payment for something new
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: She traded in her old car for the new model.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: put on a piece of clothing in order to see how it looks and whether it fits
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I'll try this dress on.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: watch or listen to a TV or radio programme
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: Make sure you tune in to next week's show.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: not accept an offer or request, reject an offer, invitation etc.
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: They offered her the job, but she turned it down. / His application for a visa has been turned down.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: reduce the amount of something (sound, heat, or light)
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: He decided to go upstairs and ask the young men to turn down their music.
Tadpoles turned into frogs.
I turned the TV off and went to bed.
Will you turn on the lights, please?
The factory turns out three thousands units a day.
It looked as if we were going to fail, but it turned out well in the end. / The experiments with the new fertilizer turned out very well.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: emerge, become apparent, prove to be, end up
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: It turned out that they had known each other for a long time. / Though we were initially suspicious of him, he turned out to be reliable person.
She didn't turn up for class today. / That lost ring will turn up somewhere, I am sure.
Will you turn up the radio, please?
We used up all the olive oil.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: waver between, fluctuate between, oscillate between
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: I tend to vacillate between admiration and pity for him.
Our troops warded off the enemy attack.
Some people take vitamin pills to ward off cold and flu.
Players should always warm up before a match.
The anesthetic wore off and my tooth started hurting.
The effects of the drug will wear off in a few hours.
Children's clothes wear out very quickly. / She played the video so many times that she wore the type out.
Mrs. Smith, worn out by anxiety and strain, was in a desperate state.
He was weighing up the pros and cons of his decision to start his own business.
The regime was successful in welding together many diverse elements: religious, ethnic and linguistic.
The terrorist organization wound up its activities and decided to disband.
I forgot to wind up my alarm clock and overslept.
We wound up our meeting in time for lunch. / The company was wound up when the creditors demanded payment.
A meteor crashing into the planet wiped the dinosaurs out. / Two villages were wiped out by floods.
The occupying forces will sooner or later withdraw their troops from the island.
Some athletes have withdrawn from the race as a political gesture.
His eagerness to learn German cannot be allowed to wither away.
Things were going wrong for them but fortunately it all worked out in the end.
I couldn't work out all the answers to the crossword puzzle.
I've worked out a new way of doing it.
I couldn't work out what her motives might be.
The plan worked out. / Their marriage just didn't work out.
I can't work the puzzle out.
The accountants use computers to work out our salaries.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: complete something, bring it to an end, conclude
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: The President is wrapping up his visit to Warsaw.
Peace is wrapping up in willingness to compromise.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: try to deal with, solve a difficult problem
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: For decades, mathematicians have wrestled with this problem.
I wrote her mobile number down on a scrap of paper and I've lost it.

synonyms_related_words.synonym: destroy a car in an accident
synonyms_related_words.sample_sentences: He wrote the car off in an accident on the motorway.
Last year we had to write off debts amounting to $10,000.
I'll write out the recipe for you, if you like.
